comments:
This first course in systems modeling focuses on linear discrete-time systems.
Throughout this course, necessary mathematical tools are developed, drawing on a set of
examples that demonstrate the breadth of systems models; these examples are drawn
from engineering, the biological sciences, and economics. MATLAB is used extensively.
Students had mixed feelings regarding the course content. Some thought that it
was interesting, with “some real world connections.” One student called it “an excellent
introduction to the broad concepts of recursion and dynamic systems.” Another student,
however, pointed out that the course was so abstract that he would not know “how to
apply these concepts to the real world.” A majority of the class complained about the
homework, which wasn’t “necessarily difficult”, but “impossible to answer” without TA
help due to “extremely convoluted” and ambiguous wording.
Several students were full of praise for the “wonderful” and “responsive” TAs,
whose help was essential in completing the homework. Regarding Professor
Koditschek’s teaching, one student commented that he “may have tried too hard to make
the beginning understandable and thus spent too much time on it.” As a result, a few
others noted that later topics were not covered in depth.
Many students indicated that they put a lot of effort into the class, but not all felt
that the time improved their understanding of the material. One respondent called it “a
good way for students to start with the basics of systems.”
